nodes.body:
Isn't the following lemma the real content of this PR:
```lean
theorem sub_one_mul_sum_div_pow_eq_sub_sum_digits (n : â„•) :
    (p - 1) * âˆ‘ i in Finset.Icc 1 (log p n), n / p ^ i = n - (p.digits n).sum :=
```
Maybe this could go in `Mathlib/Data/Nat/Digits.lean`?

> ```lean
> theorem sub_one_mul_sum_div_pow_eq_sub_sum_digits (n : â„•) :
>     (p - 1) * âˆ‘ i in Finset.Icc 1 (log p n), n / p ^ i = n - (p.digits n).sum :=
> ```

Yes, this would be one way to do it and is indeed a stronger result (since it does not depend on p being prime). 
However I tried to proof this first and failed. This was due mainly because the paper proof that we can easily write down for this e.g. see [French](https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formule_de_Legendre) and [English](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Legendre%27s_formula)  wikipedia, liberally manipulate the double sums, implicitly adding zero summands, which seems to be quite cumbersome to replicate in lean.

If there's an easy way to proof this, I'd be happy to add this lemma to `Mathlib/Data/Nat/Digits.lean` and make the proof of `padicValNat_factorial'` much simpler. 
I think the version that might be even more useful is to allow zero summands like so:

```lean
theorem sub_one_mul_sum_div_pow_eq_sub_sum_digits (n : â„•) {b : â„•} (hnb : log p n < b) :
     (p - 1) * âˆ‘ i in Finset.Ico 1 b, n / p ^ i = n - (p.digits n).sum :=
```
What would be the best way to prove this?

@mo271 Thank you for your work on this but I still think we should prove the result I stated so I'm going to relabel this back to "awaiting-author" until we have that.

Manipulating double sums etc. is absolutely possible in Mathlib, so this is no reason to settle for something less. However it does take some practice to become proficient. The right place to look for help learning this is on Zulip, rather than here. I encourage you to start a thread asking for help, in either the "PR Reviews" or the "maths" stream. I bet you'll get lots of good answers there.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#5778~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#5789~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#5802~~
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#6505~~

@ocfnash I used the lemma you suggested and as expected the proof is much easier!

Drive-by: actually use the variable `p` defined separately as is elsewhere in this file...

:v: mo271 can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
Thanks for the review! I also replaced `padicValNat_factorial'` (with a "`'`")  by the new name `sub_one_mul_padicValNat_factorial_eq_sub_sum_digits`
bors r+

Thanks!

bors d+

```suggestion
## Calculations with `p`-adic valuations
```

```suggestion
  apply n.strongInductionOn
```

```suggestion
  rcases n.eq_zero_or_pos with rfl | hnp; simp
```

Note that according to the [style guide](https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/style.html#tactic-mode)

> Very short goals can be closed right away using swap or work_on_goal if needed, to avoid additional indentation in the rest of the proof.

so it is acceptable, and I claim preferable, to dispense with the `n = 0` branch using `; simp`

You should then drop the `Â· ` and remove the intendation from the rest of the proof.
done

```suggestion
      rw [this, mul_add, hn (n / p) (Nat.div_lt_self hnp hp.out.one_lt)]
```

```suggestion
      rw [digits_def' hp.out.one_lt hnp]
```

```suggestion
          Nat.sub_add_cancel <| le_mul_of_pos_left hp.out.pos, mul_comm]
```

I think we should keep these brackets:
```suggestion
    padicValNat p (n !) = âˆ‘ i in Finset.Ico 1 b, n / p ^ i :=
```

```suggestion
theorem sub_one_mul_padicValNat_factorial_eq_sub_sum_digits [hp : Fact p.Prime] (n : â„•):
    (p - 1) * padicValNat p (n !) = n - (p.digits n).sum := by
  rw [padicValNat_factorial <| lt_succ_of_lt <| lt.base (log p n), â† Finset.sum_Ico_add' _ 0 _ 1,
    Ico_zero_eq_range, â† sub_one_mul_sum_log_div_pow_eq_sub_sum_digits]
```

```suggestion
  result stated in the language of `p`-adic valuations and
  `sub_one_mul_padicValNat_factorial_eq_sub_sum_digits` for a related result.
```
